subject: Re: [junit] Multiple assertions per test
msgSnippet: I m in two minds. One assertion per test case produces clean code and it s a noble sentiment I strive towards, but when test cases involve talking to software
messageBody:
I'm in two minds. One assertion per test case produces clean code and
it's a noble sentiment I strive towards, but when test cases involve
talking to software outside of my control (by which I mean
poorly-implemented third party applications) the temptation to have
multiple assertions in a single test case is sometimes too great.

I certainly agree that when it _has_ to happen, ordering assertions by
complexity is a smart move.
--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Ernst Reissner wrote:
> Hello,
> if all talk about multiple asserts, maybe i should do so as well:
> i confess: i also use multiple assertions:
> very often i have one test(method) per method (to be tested).
> Within this test i start with the most basic ones.
> If those fail.. well then it is quite unlikely that the others pass,
> but be it as it be:
> i have to fix the most basic bugs first.
>
>
> Thus it is not a problem that the other failures are masked,
> it is an advantage.
>
> The ordering of the assertions to be checked within a test
> have their own meaning.
>
> Maybe that's pretty much like Andreas way of testing.
